docs.abstract: With midterm elections looming and candidates exploiting more tools to reach voters directly, Sydney Ember, a politics reporter, makes sure her phone stays charged.
docs.snippet: With midterm elections looming and candidates exploiting more tools to reach voters directly, Sydney Ember, a politics reporter, makes sure her phone stays charged.
docs.lead_paragraph: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Sydney Ember, a politics reporter for The Times, discussed the tech she’s using.

headline.main: Staying Plugged In (for Hundreds of Miles) on the Campaign Trail
headline.print_headline: Tech and Reporting on the Campaign Trail

docs.abstract: Two groups in particular — whites without a college degree, and black and Hispanic college graduates — have lagged as incomes and wealth have grown.
docs.snippet: Two groups in particular — whites without a college degree, and black and Hispanic college graduates — have lagged as incomes and wealth have grown.
docs.lead_paragraph: Americans’ household earnings are finally stretching back to their pre-recession heights. But feeling secure and comfortable isn’t only a measure of how much money you have. It’s also a measure of how much you have compared with others.

headline.main: Even in Better Times, Some Americans Seem Farther Behind. Here’s Why.
headline.print_headline: In Financial Comeback, Some Groups Still Lagging

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Federal Reserve Bank of St Louis

docs.abstract: Several prominent chief executives are considering running for president. But “the history of business leaders in the White House has not been good.”
docs.snippet: Several prominent chief executives are considering running for president. But “the history of business leaders in the White House has not been good.”
docs.lead_paragraph: Since Donald Trump was unexpectedly elected president on Nov. 8, 2016, speculation has swirled about whether another well-known business leader might make a bid for the White House in 2020.

headline.main: Schultz 2020? Other C.E.O.s Will Be Watching Closely

docs.abstract: Private-sector optimism is widespread, with risks from tariffs, deficits and global tensions outweighed by profit-plumping tax cuts and deregulation.
docs.snippet: Private-sector optimism is widespread, with risks from tariffs, deficits and global tensions outweighed by profit-plumping tax cuts and deregulation.
docs.lead_paragraph: Potential perils are in plain sight: An intense and unpredictable tariff battle is alarming businesses across the country. The annual federal deficit is heading toward $1 trillion. Credit card debt is soaring. And the synchronous wave that lifted every world economy at the year’s start has dissipated.

headline.main: U.S. Businesses Are Bullish Amid Worldwide Instability
headline.print_headline: U.S. Businesses Feeling Bullish, Despite Tumult

docs.abstract: Stranded in Dubai, the 377-foot Luna is fought over by a Russian oligarch who refuses to hand over a penny to his ex-wife.
docs.snippet: Stranded in Dubai, the 377-foot Luna is fought over by a Russian oligarch who refuses to hand over a penny to his ex-wife.
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON — With a spa, a swimming pool, two heliports and room for 18 guests, the Luna is more like a floating luxury villa than a yacht. A crew of 50 keep all nine decks in pristine shape. The lifeboats cost $4 million apiece. Gleaming engines propel the vessel at a maximum speed of 22 knots.

headline.main: A Russian Oligarch’s $500 Million Yacht Is in the Middle of Britain’s Costliest Divorce
headline.print_headline: A Bitter Custody Battle for a $500 Million Boat

docs.abstract: Federal Reserve will release the minutes from its September meeting, when it raised interest rates. And data on retail sales and housing will come out.
docs.snippet: Federal Reserve will release the minutes from its September meeting, when it raised interest rates. And data on retail sales and housing will come out.
docs.lead_paragraph: Here’s what to expect in the week ahead:

headline.main: Big Banks’ Earnings and China Growth Report to Give Snapshots of Economies
headline.print_headline: Retail Sales for September And China Growth Data

docs.abstract: Stephen A. Schwarzman of Blackstone and Laurence D. Fink of BlackRock were the latest to cancel amid furor over the disappearance of a Saudi journalist.
docs.snippet: Stephen A. Schwarzman of Blackstone and Laurence D. Fink of BlackRock were the latest to cancel amid furor over the disappearance of a Saudi journalist.
docs.lead_paragraph: The chief executives of the Blackstone Group and BlackRock have canceled plans to attend an investment conference in Saudi Arabia next week, people with direct knowledge of the matter said on Monday, joining Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase as the latest Wall Street titans to pull back in the wake of the disappearance, and potential murder of a prominent Saudi journalist.

headline.main: Blackstone and BlackRock Chiefs Withdraw From Saudi Conference
headline.print_headline: More Executives Pull Out Of Investment Conference

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced and Andrew Ross Sorkin

docs.abstract: With fake pages and sham accounts, the military targeted the mostly Muslim Rohingya minority group, said former military officials, researchers and civilian officials.
docs.snippet: With fake pages and sham accounts, the military targeted the mostly Muslim Rohingya minority group, said former military officials, researchers and civilian officials.
docs.lead_paragraph: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar — They posed as fans of pop stars and national heroes as they flooded Facebook with their hatred. One said Islam was a global threat to Buddhism. Another shared a false story about the rape of a Buddhist woman by a Muslim man.

headline.main: A Genocide Incited on Facebook, With Posts From Myanmar’s Military
headline.print_headline: Genocide Across Myanmar, Incited on Facebook

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

docs.abstract: As India develops new rules governing the data of its residents, global firms are the first target. Companies say they need more time to comply.
docs.snippet: As India develops new rules governing the data of its residents, global firms are the first target. Companies say they need more time to comply.
docs.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — When the clock struck midnight in Delhi at the end of Monday, Visa, Mastercard and American Express were suddenly in violation of the law every time an Indian swiped a credit or debit card.

headline.main: U.S. Credit Card Giants Flout India’s New Law on Personal Data
headline.print_headline: New Law in India Is a Problem for U.S. Companies

docs.abstract: Micron, an American chip maker, says its designs were swiped to help a new Chinese plant. Washington sees a larger pattern, fueling tensions with Beijing.
docs.snippet: Micron, an American chip maker, says its designs were swiped to help a new Chinese plant. Washington sees a larger pattern, fueling tensions with Beijing.
docs.lead_paragraph: JINJIANG, China — With a dragnet closing in, engineers at a Taiwanese chip maker holding American secrets did their best to conceal a daring case of corporate espionage.

headline.main: Inside a Heist of American Chip Designs, as China Bids for Tech Power
headline.print_headline: Darker Side Of Tech Bid By China
